docs.lead_paragraph: If a flu pandemic strikes and supplies must be stretched, there will be no safe way to decontaminate a disposable face mask before reusing it, a panel said.

headline.main: Experts See Hurdles to Reusing Masks in Event of a Flu Pandemic

docs.lead_paragraph: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital broke ground yesterday on a cardiac center that hospital officials said would greatly expand its research capabilities and contribute to battling cardiovascular diseases. The hospital is regarded as a leader in procedures like robotically assisted open-heart surgery.

headline.main: Hospital Breaks Ground for Cardiac Center

docs.abstract: New York-Presbyterian Hospital breaks ground for cardiac center on campus of Columbia University Medical Center in Manhattan; photo (M)
docs.snippet: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital broke ground yesterday on a cardiac center that hospital officials said would greatly expand its research capabilities and contribute to battling cardiovascular diseases.

docs.lead_paragraph: If a flu pandemic strikes, there will be no safe way to decontaminate a disposable face mask so it can be reused, a panel of medical experts said yesterday. The thicker of the two kinds of disposable masks can be reused if it has been protected by a plastic face shield or a thinner mask worn over it, said the Institute of Medicine panel, which included experts in infectious diseases and fabric engineering. But even then, the wearer must be careful not to touch it with unwashed hands.

headline.main: Experts See Hurdles to Reusing Masks in Event of a Flu Pandemic

docs.lead_paragraph: The next wave of drug lawsuits is coming. As Merck reels from 11,500 suits over Vioxx, its arthritis drug, the rest of the industry is girding for challenges over another half a dozen widely used medications that plaintiffs' lawyers say have hidden and severe side effects or were improperly marketed.

headline.main: In the Money, And in Court; Drug Industry Braces for New Suits Over Even More of Its Products

docs.abstract: Drug industry girds for challenges over half dozen widely used medications, still on market, that allegedly have hidden and severe side effects or were improperly marketed; lawyers are trying to link suits involving Seroquel, antipsychotic medicine from AstraZeneca, Ortho-Evra birth control patch from Johnson & Johnson, Prempro, hormone therapy for women from Wyeth and Fosamax, osteoporosis medicine from Merck, to Vioxx litigation; drawing; chart (M)
docs.snippet: The drug industry is girding for challenges over another half a dozen widely used medications that plaintiffs' lawyers say have hidden and severe side effects or were improperly marketed.
